physdesc.extent: 1 legal document box, 2 letter-size document boxes, and 82 film canisters

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. When requesting to view audiovisual material, please refer to the Title and the AV Number (example: AV 1916).
Researchers are asked to check the "Restrictions" note for each Title. If a Title does not currently have an access copy, please contact a RAC archivist for further instruction.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Robert H. Kokernot papers document Kokernot's daily work and travels as a staff member of the Rockefeller Foundation's arbovirus research program in South Africa from 1954-1960 and in Colombia from 1962-1963. The papers also provide a personal view into the social and domestic life of a white American family in apartheid South Africa in the 1950s.
Robert Kokernot's collection also includes films documenting both his research expeditions and his family's activities and travel.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Peggy Kokernot Kaplan donated the Robert H. Kokernot papers to the Rockefeller Archive Center as an unrestricted gift on November 30, 2017.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Additional materials relating to Robert H. Kokernot are found in the Rockefeller Foundation records, including Officers' Diaries (FA392) (a partial copy of his diaries for 1954-1957); FA425 and FA400, General Correspondence for 1954-1956 and 1958-1963; and a Biographical File in FA1280, Secretary's Office, RG 15, series 4. Other materials include a correspondence file in the Kenneth C. Smithburn papers (FA040), and a file in the John C. Bugher papers (FA027).
Kokernot's correspondence with Edith May Babcock, 1943-1946, is found in the Texas A and M University archives.

physdesc.extent: 1 legal document box, 2 letter-size document boxes; 1 flat file folder, and 6 DVDs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Robert H. Kokernot was a staff member of the Johannesburg arbovirus laboratory from 1954 to 1960. His professional papers consist of the official diaries he kept of his laboratory work and his field expeditions into Mozambique, the Caprivi Strip and Bechuanaland Protectorate, and Angola, and of his exploratory travel in Colombia in 1962-1963. Diary notes from his home leaves in 1956 and 1958 also include details of visits with Rockefeller Foundation officers and colleagues. The file includes articles reporting on results of Kokernot's research in Africa and his subsequent work in the U.S. While there is little professional correspondence in the file, Kokernot's personal letters home sometimes include details on his travel and research.

The Family Correspondence files consist primarily of letters from Kokernot and his wife Edith Babcock Kokernot to Robert's mother and stepfather, Lucy (Moss Kokernot) and Ray White, in Chico, CA. Living abroad with three young children, Edith and Robert wrote letters detailing the children's growth, schooling, friends, and holidays; their own activities and social life; the family's travels in South Africa; and their travels to and from home.

In retirement, Kokernot wrote an autobiographical account of his life up to the 1970s, and he compiled a volume about his travel and research in Africa and Colombia. These accounts reproduce various sections of his diaries and his film guides.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File consists primarily of letters from Robert Kokernot and Edith Babcock Kokernot to Robert's parents, Lucy and Ray White, in Chico, CA. Subjects concern daily life in South Africa, the children's growth and activities, health, social life, and travel, as well as the progress of Robert's research and field work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Covers period January 29, 1954 - December 1956. Entries for 1956 tend to be summary reports. Diary entries document Kokernot's laboratory research, field work, and travel in South Africa as a staff member of the Rockefeller Foundation's virus laboratory. The volume also includes a summary of Kokernot's activities while absent from Johannesburg, March 22 - July 23, 1956.

This diary volume closely parallels the copy of his diary found in the Rockefeller Foundation records, Officers' Diaries. But there are some differences between them, particularly for entries toward the end of 1955 and 1956.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Diary covers January 1, 1957 - August 31, 1959. Includes field trips to Portuguese East Africa (Mozambique), July 11 - August 23, 1957; Lumbo, Mozambique, March 11 - April 8, 1959; and Caprivi Strip and Bechuanaland Protectorate, May 25 - July 2, 1959.
Note that this volume includes entries for August-December 1957 that are not found in the Rockefeller Foundation records, Officers' Diaries volume for that year.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File consists of loose diary pages that had been inserted at the back of the 1957-1959 volume.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Trips to Portuguese East Africa (Mozambique), 1957 July 11 - August 23; Lumbo, Mozambique, 1959 March 11 - April 8; Caprivi Strip and Bechuanaland Protectorate, 1959 May 25 - July 2: Portuguese West Africa (Angola), 1960 May 27 - June 23; Colombia, Llanos and Amazonas, 1962 August 26 - September 3.

did.unittitle: Diary Notes - Home Leaves from South Africa

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Home leaves March 22 - July 23, 1956, and June 18 - November 8, 1958. Copies of pages from Kokernot's diary volumes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File also includes a leather passport case embossed with the Rockefeller Foundation's logo and Kokernot's Rockefeller Foundation - issued travel ID.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Robert H. Kokernot, A Factual Account in the Life of a Fortunate Man: The First Six Decades, San Antonio, TX, 2002. Volumes 1 and 2, in one bound volume. Pp. i-iii, 1-240; and i-iii, 1-182.

did.unittitle: Travels in David Livingstone's Southern Africa and the Llanos and Amazonas of Columbia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Volume compiled and authored by David Kokernot. Contents consist of indexes and descriptive guides to Kokernot's films of Africa and Colombia; copies of his diaries of field trips to Mozambique, Caprivi Strip and Bechuanaland Protectorate, Angola, and Colombia, 1957-1962; reprints of his survey reports; and some introductory notes and illustrations. The diaries and film guides also exist elsewhere in the collection; but we do not have other copies for some of the survey reports.

did.unittitle: Guide to Films of Africa and Colombia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Index and description of Kokernot's 41 reels of film of Africa and Colombia. File also includes a second copy of the guide that matches a set of 6 VHS tapes to their corresponding film reels.

did.unittitle: The Kokernot Children's Early Years Living in the USA and Abroad (Guide to Videos)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Jan, Peggy, Walter, and Diana Kokernot - Their Early Years Living in the USA and Abroad - A Pictorial Account. Guide to the contents of 5 VHS cassettes (and presumably 6 DVDs of the same title). The sixth DVD includes Peggy Kokernot's interview of her paternal grandmother, Lucy Moss Kokernot White.

did.unittitle: Jan, Peggy, Walter, and Diana Kokernot - The Early Years Living in the USA and Abroad (Disk 1)
Jan, Peggy, Walter, and Diana Kokernot - The Early Years Living in the USA and Abroad (Disc 2)
Jan, Peggy, Walter, and Diana Kokernot - The Early Years Living in the USA and Abroad (Disc 3)
Jan, Peggy, Walter, and Diana Kokernot - The Early Years Living in the USA and Abroad (Disc 4)
Jan, Peggy, Walter, and Diana Kokernot - The Early Years Living in the USA and Abroad (Disc 5)
Jan, Peggy, Walter, and Diana Kokernot - The Early Years Living in the USA and Abroad, and Interview with Granny (Disc 6)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sixth DVD also includes Peggy Kokernot's interview of her paternal grandmother, Lucy Moss Kokernot White.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photocopied snapshots and images of Edith Kokernot and children, mid-1950s, and of Robert H. Kokernot in 1971. Includes photo of Kokernot daughters posing with Zulu wedding party, mid-1950s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mosquito Safari: A Naturalist in Southern Africa, by C. Brooke Worth (New York, 1971). Worth worked with Kokernot and provides accounts of some of their travels and field work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two unidentified landscape scenes. Black-and-white prints, approximately 10.5" x 16" and 10" x 14.5." The first image may be of the Rio Raposa field station. The latter image, signed by Terence Spencer, is glued to a 16" x 20" paper backing. Both images have been removed from frames.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Films remain in Robert H. Kokernot's original order.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. When requesting to view audiovisual material, please refer to the Title and the AV Number (example: AV 1916).
Researchers are asked to check the "Restrictions" note for each Title. If a Title does not currently have an access copy, please contact a RAC archivist for further instruction.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Films documenting Robert H. Kokernot's scientific work in Africa and Colombia for the Rockefeller Foundation. The Home Movies series documents his children's activities, family life, and travel in South Africa, Columbia, and the U.S.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The Rockefeller Archive Center recognizes that our audiovisual materials may contain problematic language and/or content.

The films, videos, and/or sound in this collection have not been altered in any way. All titles and/or content are illustrative of the creator's original vision. As such, this audiovisual collection may contain discriminatory visual and/or aural content that is representative of racial, gendered, or ableist biases.

Accompanying description, most often with creator or donor-generated language and terminology, has to this point been retained and maintained "as received" by RAC with minimal archivist intervention or augmentation.
We acknowledge these problems and aim to cultivate inclusive representation and equity by reconsidering and enhancing our description of this audiovisual material with current sensibilities.
